dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, um, the global economy, right? It just keeps throwing surprises at us. We've been looking at some really interesting takes on, like, how things are shaking out.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, um, the global economy, right? It just keeps throwing surprises at us. We've been looking at some really interesting takes on, like, how things are shaking out.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, totally. And one of the big things that keeps coming up is, uh, how international agreements and institutions are, well, *struggling* a bit. Like, remember when Trump imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, totally. And one of the big things that keeps coming up is, uh, how international agreements and institutions are, well, struggling a bit. Like, remember when Trump imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When former US President Donald Trump, citing national-security concerns, imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, many of the United States trading partners viewed this as a fig leaf for protectionism and filed complaints with the WTO.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah. Citing national security, but a lot of people saw that as, you know, a fig leaf for protectionism. And then the complaints went to the WTO...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah. Citing national security, but a lot of people saw that as, you know, a fig leaf for protectionism. And then the complaints went to the W T O...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When former US President Donald Trump, citing national-security concerns, imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, many of the United States trading partners viewed this as a fig leaf for protectionism and filed complaints with the WTO.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Exactly! But then America just refuses to appoint new judges to the WTO's dispute-settlement body, so now it's basically, like, non-functional. It's a huge problem.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! But then America just refuses to appoint new judges to the W T O's dispute-settlement body, so now it's basically, like, non-functional. It's a huge problem.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But Americas refusal to appoint new judges to the WTOs dispute-settlement body has left members without a functional mechanism to resolve such conflicts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. It undermines the whole system. And that kinda leads us into sanctions, which is another big tool countries use. We heard about the South Africa sanctions in the '80s being super effective, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. It undermines the whole system. And that kinda leads us into sanctions, which is another big tool countries use. We heard about the South Africa sanctions in the 'eighty seconds being super effective, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A notable example is the extensive sanctions levied against South Africa in the 1980s, which played a significant role in facilitating the downfall of the apartheid regime.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right. But that's because they were *nearly universal*. What we're seeing now, like with US-imposed trade sanctions, is that they often fail to achieve their goals, especially if they're not global.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. But that's because they were nearly universal. What we're seeing now, like with U S imposed trade sanctions, is that they often fail to achieve their goals, especially if they're not global.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Unless they are nearly universal, however, trade sanctions are often less effective than expected. As Richard Hanania observed in a 2020 Cato Institute analysis, US-imposed trade sanctions almost always fail to achieve their goals.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, because traders just find ways around it. Like Iran with its oil-smuggling network, or sanctioned Chinese goods rerouted through Vietnam and Mexico. It's pretty ingenious, honestly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, because traders just find ways around it. Like Iran with its oil-smuggling network, or sanctioned Chinese goods rerouted through Vietnam and Mexico. It's pretty ingenious, honestly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Iran, for example, has managed to circumvent Western sanctions by constructing a sophisticated oil-smuggling network. Similarly, sanctioned Chinese goods are reportedly still entering the US market, as China-based firms reroute their exports through countries like Vietnam and Mexico.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It is! Unless you have, like, near-universal participation, they just, uh, redirect goods. But then there are *financial* sanctions, right? Like during the Iraq War, where the US prevented companies from dealing with partners helping Iraq.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It is! Unless you have, like, near-universal participation, they just, uh, redirect goods. But then there are financial sanctions, right? Like during the Iraq War, where the U S prevented companies from dealing with partners helping Iraq.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: During the Iraq War, the US used financial sanctions to prevent American companies from dealing with counterparts in third-party countries that facilitated prohibited transactions with Iraq.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And those were surprisingly effective, largely because of the dollar's dominance. So, when Russia invaded Ukraine, we saw this massive, unprecedented wave of financial sanctions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And those were surprisingly effective, largely because of the dollar's dominance. So, when Russia invaded Ukraine, we saw this massive, unprecedented wave of financial sanctions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These secondary sanctions proved to be significantly more effective than traditional commodity trade sanctions, largely owing to the dollars dominant role in global finance. ... Following Russian President Vladimir Putins full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, the US and its allies imposed unprecedented trade and financial sanctions on Russia...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the technology ban, the military exports, even the $60 price cap on Russian oil, which was supposed to cripple their economy and, like, help Europe avoid an energy crisis.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the technology ban, the military exports, even the sixty dollars price cap on Russian oil, which was supposed to cripple their economy and, like, help Europe avoid an energy crisis.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Following Russian President Vladimir Putins full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, the US and its allies imposed unprecedented trade and financial sanctions on Russia, including a ban on technology and military exports. They also introduced a $60-per-barrel price cap on Russian oil, designed to cripple Russias economy while ensuring that Europe could avoid a politically destabilizing energy crisis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But, um, that hasn't quite worked out as planned, has it? The oil price didn't stay below $60; it shot up to over $84 by November 2023. Russia just developed a shadow fleet and inflated shipping costs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But, um, that hasn't quite worked out as planned, has it? The oil price didn't stay below sixty dollars; it shot up to over eighty four dollars by November twenty twenty three. Russia just developed a shadow fleet and inflated shipping costs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While financial sanctions forced oil traders to secure ships with suitable insurance coverage before finalizing transactions, the price of Russian oil did not fall below $60 per barrel. By November 2023, it had risen to $84.20 as Russian companies developed various methods of circumventing Western restrictions, such as inflated shipping costs and a shadow fleet consisting of more than 100 old tankers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And all those "laundromat" countries popping up! India, China, Armenia, even Greece... helping Russia circumvent everything. We even saw a Greek company selling Russian oil to the US military!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And all those laundromat countries popping up! India, China, Armenia, even Greece... helping Russia circumvent everything. We even saw a Greek company selling Russian oil to the U S military!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, the Russia sanctions regime has given rise to a number of intermediaries, with countries like India, China, Armenia, Greece, Turkey, the United Arab Emirates, and Singapore effectively becoming laundromats for Russian oil and other sanctioned goods. ... One Greek company even sold Russian oil to the US military.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wild. So, they're intensifying enforcement now, like the Treasury Department sanctioned 250 companies in December. But it really makes you question the effectiveness of this whole regime.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wild. So, they're intensifying enforcement now, like the Treasury Department sanctioned two hundred fifty companies in December. But it really makes you question the effectiveness of this whole regime.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In response to the mounting evidence of sanctions evasion, the US and its allies have intensified their enforcement efforts. In December, the US Treasury Department imposed sweeping sanctions on more than 250 companies and individuals, including Chinese and North Korean entities.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. I mean, yes, it's dented Russia's GDP a bit, but the evasion is so widespread. And there's this huge risk that the longer we use the global financial system as a weapon, the more countries will look for alternatives to the dollar.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. I mean, yes, it's dented Russia's G D P a bit, but the evasion is so widespread. And there's this huge risk that the longer we use the global financial system as a weapon, the more countries will look for alternatives to the dollar.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To be sure, Western sanctions have reduced Russias revenues and dented its GDP, albeit to a lesser extent than many had hoped. But the longer the global financial system is used as a tool of economic warfare, the more governments and businesses in third-party countries will look for alternatives to the dollar, euro, and the SWIFT international payment system.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which, um, could have massive long-term costs for the US economy, far outweighing any short-term benefits. It's a really complex picture, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, um, could have massive long-term costs for the U S economy, far outweighing any short-term benefits. It's a really complex picture, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Should the Russia sanctions regime significantly erode the dollars prominence in international financial markets, the cost to the US and global economies could far exceed its benefits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. We're definitely not out of the woods on this.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. We're definitely not out of the woods on this.
